instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> pulled down
threads.message:
Liquid damage on this one, I found it difficult and time consuming.

1) It had a full short on <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>, replaced the cap and short gone.

2)Next, it had <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> low voltage around 2.2V. Diode mode was showing 0.340 very similar to other working boards however resistance to ground was reading 1.9KOhm.
This was pointing to a 2kohms resistance with other end shorted to ground, indeed I found <RESISTOR>R5381</RESISTOR>-pin2 <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> full shorted to ground. Turned out to be <DIODE>D6950</DIODE> shorting the signal.

3)<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> was still reading a low short this time 0.041 in diode mode, additionnaly <SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground, this time it turned out to be <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> PMIC witch I replaced.

Now on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> I have normal readings compare to other boards 0.340 in diode mode and 21kOhm to ground
<SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> is also 0,425 diode mode

My issue: I still have 2.29V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
If I remove <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> I can see <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> outputing 3.4V If I put back <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> it is pulled down to 2,29V. <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> measures fine 0 ohm.
If I inject 3,4V on system side I have 14mA draw exactly same with working board.

Can I assume <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> are ok since I get  3,4V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> when <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> is removed? Or I am wrong as I perhaps get 3,4V only because there is no load?

<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 4,8V and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 30mV with no short at all.

I am out of idea and thats why I am here!
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> pulled down
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> needs to talk with SMC, in order to generate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
0.340 in diode mode at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> looks good, but you should check reverse way measurment too.

"<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> was still reading a low short this time 0.041"
Was this problem solved?
Must get very similar readings on both SCL/SDA lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> pulled down
threads.message:
Reverse diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is normal 1.240 and comparable with other working boards.

Yes diode mode 0.041 on  <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL>  was solved it was <DIODE>D6950</DIODE> shorting partially to ground.

I decided to inject 5V on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> Vin and enable. It produced 3,4V when 5V was applied after <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>, I mean pin 3 of <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.
It produced 2.2V when 5V was applied before <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> (<DIODE>D6905</DIODE>-Pin2).

At that point I knew something was wrong upstream from <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>-Pin2.
I found out odd diode mode reading on <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.

Black probe on pin3 Red proble on pin 1: Diode mode reading 0.201 ok
Black probe on pin3 Red proble on pin 2: Diode mode reading 0.569 -> should be 0,201 compared to other boards

Reverse diode mesurement was ok.
Replaced <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> and got stable 3.4V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and nice 13,5V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. didn't know this would affect <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at that point!

After that: I had to replace <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> because it simply never produced <SIGNAL>5V_LDO</SIGNAL>...

Now board fully boots, I have to solve battery detected but not charging...

This is a very nice nightmare practice board with almost 6 different faults completely unrelated on each other...
